pr_title: `WriteStreamSubscriber` retains listeners for the lifetime of the source

timeline.message:
`WriteStreamSubscriber` retains listeners for the lifetime of the source

__Motivation__

`WriteStreamSubscriber` uses a single `Promise` for all writes done through it. As we add listeners to each write, the listeners get accumulated in the promise till the `WriteStreamSubscriber` terminates. For servers since we do a single write for the connection, these listeners are retained for the connection lifetime.

__Modification__

- Manage listeners in `AllWritesPromise` as opposed to delegating them to `DefaultWritePromise`.
- Listeners are managed over the specific write boundaries.
- Each time a write is complete, listeners added since last write are terminated and removed from the list.

__Result__

Listeners are retained by `WriteStreamSubscriber` for the duration of each write.

timeline.author: Scottmitch

timeline.bodyText: did you consider random insertion or removal to be common (I'm assuming removeListener isn't frequently used)? if not consider ArrayDeque which has a lower constant memory overhead (LinkedList = 24 bytes per Node, ArrayDeque = backed by array).
timeline.author: Scottmitch
Scottmitch

replies.bodyText: Let me try this out, thanks
replies.author: NiteshKant

replies.bodyText:
Ok doing this will have problems if the write completes synchronously with channel.write() call.
listenersOnWriteBoundaries <- empty
channel.write()
   - addListener(listener1) => listenersOnWriteBoundaries (listener1)
   - writeAndFlush() (internally in the pipeline) => drain  listenersOnWriteBoundaries <- empty
add WRITE_BOUNDARY to listenersOnWriteBoundaries
channel.write()
    - addListener(listener2) => listenersOnWriteBoundaries (WRITE_BOUNDARY, listener2)
flush()
notifyListenersTillNextWrite() <- removes WRITE_BOUNDARY and exits
replies.author: NiteshKant

replies.bodyText: I have replaced the early-return with an assert
replies.author: NiteshKant
Scottmitch

timeline.bodyText: I see the we assume no late listener comment above but I'm wondering what the negative/costs would be of notifying listeners if they are late. Otherwise if this does happen we may not complete async control flow in some cases. We maybe able to delegate to super to manage notification, however not sure if this will bring up any notification ordering if folks add a listener in a re-entry fashion.
timeline.author: Scottmitch

replies.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText:
Re: late listeners
What I was struggling with was that how do we distinguish between a late listener and a listener for the next write.
replies.author: NiteshKant

replies.bodyText:
how do we distinguish between a late listener and a listener for the next write.

This is a good point, I guess we really can't. Now that we are tracking listeners for individual write operations I wonder if AllWritesPromise still makes sense? An alternative would be to allocate new promises and have a shared listener that counts success/failures and manages the state ... wdyt?
replies.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText: Ya creating new promises is what I thought initially but since it has perf implications, I decided to not make such a drastic change.
replies.author: NiteshKant

timeline.bodyText: nit: consider making this method static
timeline.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText: Actually, this made me notice that I can use DefaultPromise.notifyListener()  which provides stack overflow protection 🎉
replies.author: NiteshKant

timeline.bodyText: Consider making this a GenericFutureListener. This was can tighten up the generics for the queue.
timeline.author: normanmaurer

timeline.bodyText: removeFirst() -> pollFirst() (you have already verified there is an item in the queue, you can avoid the null check/exception from remove* method)
timeline.author: Scottmitch
